signature.instructions:
text
Task: Extract ONLY the tiny set of “gold-like” uncertainty/vagueness spans from a clinical bedside-handover transcript, matching gold boundaries extremely tightly (IoU-scored).

INPUT
- One field: text
- text is a verbatim bedside-handover transcript with speaker tags like:
  [OUTGOING_NURSE], [INCOMING_NURSE], [PATIENT]
- Treat the transcript as raw text: punctuation, colons, commas, and periods matter.

OUTPUT (STRICT)
- Return ONLY a JSON list named pred_spans (no extra keys, no commentary, no markdown).
- Each element must be exactly:
  {"label": "<one of the label set>", "quote": "<exact verbatim substring from text>"}
- "quote" MUST be an exact substring copied character-for-character from text (including punctuation and leading ":" if present).
- Do not output Python dicts; output valid JSON with double quotes.

LABEL SET (use these exact strings)
- "Hedge / Probability Language"
- "Vague / Qualitative Expression"
- "Unknown fact / Explicit Lack of Knowledge"
- "Indefinite Timing"
- "Source Uncertainty"
- "Procedural Uncertainty"
- "Responsibility Uncertainty"

SCORING / STRATEGY
- Evaluation is IoU span matching against a SMALL gold set.
- PRIORITIZE PRECISION over recall: only extract patterns that are repeatedly gold-annotated.
- Gold spans often include “odd” boundaries (include comma/period/leading colon if it is in the gold-like chunk). When you see a known pattern, copy the whole gold-favored clause, not just the trigger word.

GOLD-FAVORED PATTERNS TO EXTRACT (high priority)
1) Stable / normal-range vitals phrasing → "Vague / Qualitative Expression"
   Extract the full minimal clause that gold tends to take, e.g.:
   - "Observations are stable." (include trailing period if present)
   - "He’s otherwise stable and for monitoring." (often includes the continuation)
   - "Blood pressure has been within normal range for him"
   - "vitals stable," (note the trailing comma can be part of gold)
   Keep the subject + “stable/within normal range” together. Don’t truncate to just “stable”.

2) Monitoring / close monitoring / ongoing phrasing → "Vague / Qualitative Expression"
   Gold may include a leading colon from the transcript turn, e.g.:
   - ": He remains under close monitoring"
   Include the leading ":" if it is contiguous in the text.

3) “Given / started / running / completed” care-delivery vagueness → "Vague / Qualitative Expression"
   Gold in this dataset often marks these as vague even though they sound factual. Prefer extracting these exact compact fragments:
   - "I’ve completed his initial observations"
   - "He’s started on oral antibiotics"
   - "He’s on ongoing IV fluids at" (yes, gold may stop at “at”)
   - "IV at 125 mL/hr running"
   - "oral antibiotics" (can be gold as a very short fragment)
   Boundary rule: match gold-like truncations; do NOT append extra details (rates, outcomes, “with good effect”, etc.) unless the phrase itself in text is exactly part of the compact fragment above.

4) Indefinite timing / not scheduled exactly → "Indefinite Timing"
   Extract the combined clause when timing uncertainty is expressed across adjacent words, e.g.:
   - "Sometime this afternoon there is no exact time yet."
   Prefer one combined span instead of splitting into two.
   Also extract:
   - "next dose can be given after his lunch."
   (Include the trailing period if present.)

5) Explicit unknown/unclear documentation facts → "Unknown fact / Explicit Lack of Knowledge"
   Extract compact clauses with “not confirmed yet”, “unknown”, “unclear”, “need to clarify”, especially about charting/allergies/history. Keep it as one natural clause.

6) Responsibility/task-due items (only when clearly a gold-like “due/needs doing” task) → "Responsibility Uncertainty"
   Extract minimal “needs changed/needs to be done/due for …” task clauses, e.g.:
   - "The cannular looks like it needs changed it has been in for 3 days."
   - "He’s due for MRSA and VRE surveillance swabs"
   - ": Not yet we still need to do them"
   IMPORTANT: Do NOT overuse this label for meds that are simply “due now” unless it matches the established gold-like task templates. (In prior feedback, "is due for analgesia now" was not gold.)

7) “For surgery” fragment → "Source Uncertainty"
   Extract ONLY: "She’s for surgery" / "He’s for surgery" (do not expand).

8) Provenance-limited hedge like “to me” → "Hedge / Probability Language"
   Extract compact clauses like: "no new allergies disclosed to me"

WHAT TO AVOID (common false positives)
- Do NOT extract general plan uncertainty or workflow uncertainty:
  "doctors haven’t reviewed yet", "not sure of the plan", “awaiting review” (unless it matches one of the specific gold templates above).
- Do NOT mark routine scheduled times as indefinite unless explicitly uncertain (e.g., “no exact time yet”, “sometime”).
- Avoid generic conditionals (“if you need it”, “once I’ve checked”, “follow up”, etc.).
- Avoid subjective nursing status phrases unless they match the stable/monitoring templates above.

SPAN BOUNDARY RULES (critical; optimize IoU)
- Exact substring only; no normalization.
- Keep spans minimal BUT aligned to gold-favored clause boundaries:
  - Include punctuation that is part of the clause (comma/period) when present in text and likely part of gold (e.g., "Observations are stable.", "vitals stable,").
  - If a leading ":" is present immediately before the clause in the transcript, include it (e.g., ": He remains under close monitoring").
- Avoid overlapping/duplicate spans from the same sentence; choose the single most gold-like clause.

FINAL CHECK BEFORE OUTPUT
- Validate each label is exactly from the label set.
- Validate each quote appears verbatim in text.
- Output ONLY: {"pred_spans": [...]} is NOT allowed. Output ONLY the JSON list named pred_spans (i.e., the raw list itself).
